Sherbet (pronounced “shur-bit”) is the standard American spelling for the frozen mixture made from fruit and an additive of either milk, egg white, or gelatin. It comes from the name of a Persian drink made of fruit juice, water, sweetener, and a cooling component such as snow. This refreshment was called sharbat after the Arabic word sharbah for “a drink.” Sherbert (pronounced “shur-bert”) is a common misspelling of sherbet that resulted from a common mispronunciation. Its prevalence has resulted in its inclusion in some dictionaries as an alternative spelling.

Both pronunciations will get you a scoop of a light, frozen, fruit-based refreshment in the US. But take note that if you order sherbet in the UK you may get something else entirely. In British English, sherbet is more commonly used to refer to a sweet powder that can be made into an effervescent drink by adding water.

Sherbet is distinct from ice cream primarily by its level of butterfat: in the US, sherbet must contain between 1 and 2 percent butterfat, whereas ice cream must have least 10 percent. Sherbet might also be confused with sorbet, the name for which also comes from the Arabic sharbah. Unlike sherbet, sorbet does not contain dairy, making it a great alternative for those who are lactose intolerant.

Let me start by saying that I think this series is awesome and extremely helpfull! However, I heard an error in this episode and I don't think anyone has commented on it, thus I feel obliged to take on the responsibility of correcting it before more viewers take away erroneous information:
At one point Hank says "The visual cortex sits at the back of the brain in the occipital lobe, where the right cortex processes input from the LEFT EYE and vise versa." The right cortex actually porcesses input from the LEFT VISUAL FIELD and vice versa, because half of the fibers from each eye are crossed at the optic chiasm. This leads to the axons carrying information from light entering on the left side of each eye (left visual field) to be sent to the right visual cortext, and information from the right visual field to be sent to the left cortex. This is a pretty complex process and I don't think they would've had time to go into here (khan academy has a video on it), but I just wanted to clear up the error.
Otherwise, great job with this show!

Depending on what kind of blindness a person has, it may still be polite to smile at them, because they respond even if they don't know you are doing it. Just like Hank mentioned, the brain processes different parts of vision in multiple centers. These centers are in different locations and evolved during different periods in evolution. Guess what is really cool about that, yet still sad in some ways. If a blind persons eyes actually work, but the portion of the brain that brings your vision to your consciousness is damaged or just not functioning, blind people can still respond to visual stimulation. The part of your brain that reacts to other peoples emotions comes from an area that evolved in a different location much later than basic conscious sight. You can have a person with this kind of blindness look at random images, and see on a brain scan that they still to some degree respond to human faces.

I'd like to chime in with a linguist's perspective, on sherbert.  While the original word may have been sherbet, it is important to note that language is very dynamic and changes over time.  Sherbert has come into being the same way so many other English words have come into being, from having been "borrowed" from other languages and initially misspoken. Now sherbert is a correct word.  And you can test this by trying to communicate with someone.  Nitpicking aside, if the other person understands what you mean when you say "sherbert," you have successfully communicated.  Even if the other person doesn't consider "sherbert" to be textbook correct.  The word is different, though, which is why linguists catalog dialects as different languages.  If I'm not too badly mistaken, the word pronounced sherbert comes from the Southern American English language set.  Michael Aranda might raise his eyebrow at that pronunciation, because he's from California (right?), and there's a different regional language there. :)

just a little thing i picked up on... just to tell you about my background, i study psychology at university in the uk, first year. anyway, you know when you say that imput from the right eye is being processed by left side of the visual cortex and vice versa? it's not as simple as that. basically, just like on the picture you provide in the video, the stimulus from the outer half of your eye is processed in the closest hemisphere (outside half of the left eye in the left side of visual cortex) and what you see with the inner half of your eye is being processed in a further side of visual cortex (inner half of left eye in the right side). if you look at the "lines" in the picture on the right-hand side at 8:50 it's really self-explanatory. it's a common misconception out lecturer warned us about, just thought i let you know :) probably just generalization or a common mistake, other than that brilliant series, im just using them now for revision! thank you :)

I respect your knowledge but I do believe a lot of recognition of any particular object/phenomenon is not always due to lack of sensation in the brain. It is a focus issue. You will not focus on what bores or not interest you at the time of perception. The mind may take on random thoughts at any time. When these random thoughts occur, you are not going to be able to focus on any one particular thing. Hence if you don't recognize your friend/acquaintance while in a random thought is not a reason to assume the person has a lack of sensation or any other abnormality. A lot of older people have trained their brain to ignore a lot events due to experience. To imply that someone has a problem simply because they don't comply to the rules that govern normal behavior set forth (by man)  is in my opinion only a way to control the thoughts of humans..... 

The power of suggestion is something that shouldn't be taken lightly!

The right side of the brain doesn't just get information from the left eye. It gets information from the entire left visual field, in both eyes. Check that diagram at 8:22 again! Half the nerve fibers from each eye cross over to the opposite side of the brain, but half of them stay on the same side -- so that all the visual information about stuff on the left side goes to the right half of the brain, and vice versa. This becomes really important if you're planning on talking about split-brain stuff, which I hope you are, because it's awesome. #neuroscience #correction

There was a little slip up when he was talking about the eyes, because the right side of the occipital cortex does not receive only signals from the left "eye", it  receives signals from the left "side" ( 8:30 ).  The optical signals are divided between the hemispheres by right and left visual field.  You can easily see this by closing your eyes, looking to the left as far as possible, then gently touching the right side of your right eye, applying little pressure.  You will "see" your finger on your far left because the rods stimulated believe that they are receiving light from the left side.
